dataset.title: Multi-API Database SKU Catalog 2025
dataset.description: Comprehensive catalog of database services that support multiple API patterns (SQL, NoSQL document, key-value, graph, search) to analyze industry convergence toward unified multi-API offerings
dataset.topic: Multi-API SKU Catalogs / Database Industry Convergence
dataset.metric: Multi-API support patterns and pricing models across vendors

source.methodology: Knowledge-based research supplemented with vendor documentation review
source.license: Research use - vendor information is publicly available
source.credibility: Tier A - Official vendor documentation and service specifications

platform.description: Service platform or product family name

sku_id.description: Unique identifier for the specific service SKU

sku_name.description: Human-readable product name as marketed by vendor

apis_supported.description: List of API patterns supported by this SKU
apis_supported.encoding: JSON array format within CSV string

gateway_default.description: Whether multi-API access is enabled by default (true) or requires additional configuration/services (false)
gateway_default.significance: Key indicator of true multi-API convergence vs bolt-on capabilities

first_listed_date.description: Date when this specific SKU was first made available
first_listed_date.methodology: Based on public announcements, press releases, and service launch dates

pricing_model.description: Primary pricing structure for the service

product_page_url.description: URL to main product marketing page
product_page_url.purpose: Reference for pricing and positioning analysis

unified_gateway_era.characteristics: Default multi-API support with unified gateways

Microsoft_Azure.strategy: Unified Cosmos DB platform with specialized API surfaces

AWS.approach: Specialized services with some cross-API capabilities
AWS.strategy: Service-specific optimization with limited multi-API convergence

pricing_convergence_patterns.trend: Movement toward consumption-based pricing for multi-API services

quality_indicators.confidence: High - based on official vendor documentation
limitations: Launch dates are approximate based on public announcements
API capabilities may have evolved since initial launch
Pricing models simplified - actual pricing often more complex

convergence_evidence.question: Which vendors actually sell unified multi-API SKUs vs separate API-specific products?
convergence_evidence.finding: Microsoft leads with 100% unified approach, while AWS maintains 80% service specialization. Independent vendors show 63% multi-API default support.

temporal_trends.question: How has this changed over time (2020-2025)?
temporal_trends.finding: Clear acceleration in multi-API defaults after 2020, with 75% of new services launched with gateway_default=true

pricing_strategy.question: What's the pricing strategy difference between unified vs separate SKUs?
pricing_strategy.finding: Multi-API services trend toward consumption-based pricing (per-RU, per-operation) while single-API services use infrastructure-based pricing

usage_notes: APIs_supported field uses JSON array format within CSV - parse accordingly
Gateway_default=true indicates true multi-API convergence vs bolt-on capabilities
First_listed_date represents initial service availability, not API capability additions
Pricing_model is simplified - actual vendor pricing often includes multiple components
URLs provided for validation and further research
Dataset focuses on production-ready services, excludes beta/preview offerings

thesis_support.primary_evidence: 63% of cataloged services now support multi-API access by default, with clear acceleration after 2020
convergence_indicators: Microsoft's unified Cosmos DB platform across 5 API types
Independent vendors leading with native multi-API support
Pricing model evolution toward consumption-based for multi-API services
thesis_support.industry_implications: Data supports thesis of industry convergence toward unified multi-API database SKUs, with traditional cloud vendors adapting to competitive pressure from database-native companies
